course.subject: HUMA
course.name: History of Tea in East Asia
course.description: This course explores the history of tea in East Asia from its origins to the present day using an interdisciplinary approach. Topics covered include the development of tea culture throughout history, tea's role as a trade commodity, the dissemination and innovation in tea production technologies, and its recent re-imagining as a traditional product. The course will be a mix of lectures and discussions.

reviews.author: natttttttt
reviews.comment_content:
About tea, if you are a tea lover, you are in good advantage, if not good luck in lesson, extremely boring.
Basically you do not need to attend lesson because the essays are not really related to the content.
reviews.comment_grading:
One film comparative paper,
watch two movies related to Japanese tea master Rikyu, which one of them is really old and boring. Compare anything about the two movies which you have no idea about the expectation of the grading. Not attending lessons can still finish the paper.

One historical document paper,
select a chapter from an old book, see if its content is reliable. Also something too vague to know his grading. He gave comment on the paper, but only one or two sentences and nothing knowledgable.

One group project,
with no peer evaluation. A business proposal (yes, a business proposal in a huma course, but according to him, no need to be too business with so much figure on $$$) on starting a new tea business in Hong Kong. No presentation so do not know how a "Good" proposal is.
High marks for everyone.
Full marks: 30
Mean: 26.5
Low: 24
High: 28

One tea diary assignment,
on the start of the term, just a p/f assignment. Do it, full mark, skip it, no mark.

Tea history: mainly about China and Japan, some parts about Britain and Korea.
It may cause difficulties in understanding as there are reading materials written in 'Classical Chinese' (文言文), although there are translated versions.

I am stunned that Professor seem as an expert who can speak & read Japanese, Chinese (both Putonghua and Cantonese) and even Korean. reviews.comment_grading:
Tea diary assignment 10%
Response papers 20%
Film comparative 15%
William Melrose assignment 15%
Final Project 20% (changed to Self writing/ research about Social Media related to Tea because of COVID)
Participation 20%

I think the grading is ok.
Professor said he would give everyone A range everyone is doing great (by writing reports to justify his grading).


Only the score of Tea diary & response papers released: 10/10, all 5/5 (everyone who did them with some efforts should get full score)

reviews.comment_workload:
Acceptable for me as I HATE group project, so when the final project becames essay writing, I am kind of happy.

T-dirary assignment: you can finish it by using 10 minutes to drink one kind of tea/ tea products and write about you view and feeling for 5 days.
Or I choose to use 3 hours to do that in one day.
Insert some photos inside is helpful.

For response papers (total should be 4, each one 5%), you could finish each of them in 1-2 days, around 1-2 pages each.

Film comparative: There are 2 movies to watch, they are about a Japanese tea master Sen no Rikyū (千利休, 1522 – April 21, 1591). Around 3.5-4 hours in total, but you need to write notes while watching, so it is very time-consuming. I have used around 2-3 days.

William Melrose assignment: you need to read the book first (have e-version provided). It is not a thin book (personal opinion), so again it takes you 3-4 days to finish this essay.

Final Project: changed to essay
can choose YouTube channel, or social media like IG, Facebook.
Participation: it is shocking 20%!!!! It is very horrible for an introvert like me.
But since in zoom meeting, nearly no one open cam and no one speak up, I believe I am safe. Be careful if you take this course f2f, need to raise your hand and participate in class discussion.

reviews.author: AngieGrace
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers history of tea in East Asia (mostly China & Japan) with mentions of other places that grows tea or drinks tea frequently. The tutorial is supposed to let you taste some of the tea mentioned, but because of the pandemic (online learning), you only watch the teacher & the TA drink tea while observing the physical difference of the tea. Quite a lot of videos shown in lectures too.

Reading materials at home is not required. You'll be told to read some materials in class. A lot of them are in Chinese, but the teacher understands if you can't read Chinese. He roughly translates it for you so you can understand the main point.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teacher is okay. The lecture can get boring (probably because it's online) but it's bearable.

For the assignments, he almost never gives you a clear idea of what he wants. He wants to keep the topic broad and vague so he won't need to read similar essays.
reviews.comment_grading: The teacher grades your essay like an English teacher would. The comment I got in my first essay was "Good analysis - I do wish you would be more assertive in your intro/conclusion." Overall I think he's lenient in grading your assignment.s
reviews.comment_workload:
Tea diary, 2 essay and 1 group project. A lot of writing, so be prepared if you struggle in that area.

Tea diary: Basically just write any tea-related products that you encounter in one week. Even if it's tea-infused shampoo, it counts. Easily get 10/10.

1st essay: 5-7 pages film comparative paper.
You watch 2 movies about this historical figures and write a review (compare & contrast). You're not required to write something related to the course, even if you compare the plot or the clothing, etc (movie aspect) it's okay.

2nd essay: 5-7 pages book analysis.
Takes a bit more time since you need to read some parts of a historical document. You're required to pick a topic from the book and discuss about it, criticise "whether or not it's appropriate to be a source". You can include your own views and thoughts.

Group project: Business proposal.
You and your group needs to make a proposal for a tea-related product/business. You can sell tea, food, beauty products, etc. Anything as long as it contains tea. You can arrange a meeting with the teacher but he usually will answer it vaguely. One of the grading criteria is originality, but he also wants you to not go too crazy (so your "business" won't fail the day you start it). As long as your team works together, the project is doable. The deadline was near finals, so make sure to manage your time properly.

reviews.author: sww
reviews.comment_content: not bad lol 如果你對tea既知識好感興趣會幾開心，講下唔同種類茶既知識，中國茶日本茶西式茶咩都有，但如果只係鐘意飲茶食抹茶甜品但無興趣知d茶點種點風乾既話（我諗大部分人都係），就真係好悶，不過相比起其他huma course一堆philosophy concept，tea完全無野背，好適合想輕鬆地hea上堂既人
reviews.comment_teaching: online class上呢個course真係搞唔掂，原本佢話face to face既話tutorial會有tea tasting環節，但online class就剩係聽佢講書同偶爾直播下佢沖茶...唔掛機都對唔住自己，因為ppt圖多過字真係好悶好悶，成個course都無quiz無exam，真係無動力聽書，我諗face to face上堂會好好多既
reviews.comment_grading:
Evaluation:

10% tea diary assignment：10/10 (mean: 10)

25% film comparative paper: 24.5/25 (mean: 21.3)

15% William Melrose assignment： 13.5/15 (mean: 12.7)

30% final project: 26/30 (mean: 26.5)

20% attendance/participation：無出

Final Grade：A-

絕對唔係靚grade，懷疑佢比分超級鬆手，個個都咁高分，會比到假希望你以為會好好grade，但出到黎絕對會令你失望
reviews.comment_workload:
workload唔算多，全部都係essay，相比起exam係輕鬆d，而且佢d assignment相隔好一段時間所以會有充足時間做，但d essay會幾難寫，因為一篇係睇兩套戲一篇係睇本書入面一個chapter，所以你寫essay前已經要付出一d時間睇書睇戲做research，最慘係睇完都唔識寫完全無方向

essay既內容似教你點research多過關tea事，但anyway我覺得寫essay點都輕鬆過exam既
